We Have Been Getting Out There
White Industries attended the National Manufacturing Week held 11-13 May in Sydney. There were 200 exhibitors, 50 speakers and over 5,000 attendees. This year’s theme focused on innovation and collaboration. Sessions held discussed opportunities for manufacturers to break down the barriers to innovation. It was a great exhibition and gave White Industries the opportunity to meet both new and existing clients face to face.
Our next stop will be at the Queensland Mining and Engineering Exhibition being held in Mackay on the 26th to 28th of July. This exhibition hosts approximately 650 exhibitors and is expected to attract over 12,500 attendees. There will be live demos, free seminars and a ‘Thought Leadership Panel’ led by Mick Buffier (Chairman, World Coal Association). Craig White (Sales & Marketing Director) and Jim Stevenson (Business Development Manager) will be there representing White Industries. We welcome all our customers to attend and it would be great to see you there.

White Industries Team Congratulations to our Two New Tradesmen
After four years of being Apprentice Moulders, Luke Davidson and Adrian Lambert finished their apprenticeships last month and are now fully fledged tradesmen. Luke and Adrian were part of our annual Apprentice Intake Program.
We couldn’t be prouder of the boys for their enthusiasm and dedication to their job and we will continue to support them in growing their tradesmen skills.

Australian Business News INDUSTRY HEADLINES
Arrium will be put up for sale
The South Australian steelmaker company will be put up for sale in July. Their administrators, KordiaMentha, have been able to stablise the business since taking over in April. The Arrium Group is made up of steelworks, port and mining operation at Whyalla, Moly-Cop grinding media; and OneSteel’s manufacturing & distribution segment. The business is expected to attract a lot of interest both domestically and internationally. A global investment bank will be advising on the sale of Moly-Cop.
The sale process is expected to last six months, starting at the end of July 2016 and to be completed by the end of the year.
First High Speed Support Vessel Arrives in Oman
The Royal Navy of Oman have received the first of two 72m High Speed Support Vessel (HSSV) that have been manufactured in Australia. The contract is reported to be worth US$124.9 million. HSSV is used to support naval operations, including helicopter operations, rapid deployment of military personnel and cargo, and search and rescue operations.The second vessel is due to be delivered at the end of the year.
The Evolution of Metal Casting
Metal casting can be traced back some 5,000 years. It is one of the most important manufacturing processes in the world. We will trace the history of metal casting over our next couple of newsletters. Metal casting is crucial to modern civilisation and is an essential element to any design structure.
The beginning of metal casting…
3200 B.C. - A copper frog, the oldest known casting in existence, is cast in Mesopotamia. 2000 B.C. - Iron is discovered. 800-700 B.C. The first Chinese production of cast iron. 645 B.C. - Earliest known sand moulding (China). 233 B.C. - Cast iron ploughshares are poured in China. 500 A.D. - Cast crucible steel is first produced in India, but the process is lost until 1750 when Benjamin Huntsman reinvents it in England.
